text: I literally proposed that in Camden’s Cabinet meeting.
author: OliverCooper

text:
Talking to Hampstead residents about Camden Labour hiking charges for ordinary residents’ parking permits by 70%: making them the most expensive in England.

Over 1,000 local residents have signed our petition in the last 3 days. Add your name here 
http://www.camdenparking.com
author: OliverCooper

text: I completely agree that “Common Market 2.0” relies on passing Britain’s Withdrawal Agreement, Nick. Given that obvious fact, what success have you had in persuading Stephen, Lucy, and similarly-minded Labour MPs to back the Withdrawal Agreement? CM2.0 is dead if they don’t.
author: OliverCooper

text: Who’s a good boy that doesn’t take crap from anti-Semites? You are. You’re such a good boy.
author: OliverCooper

text: Congratulations!
author: OliverCooper

text: If you don’t ask, you don’t get. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
author: OliverCooper

text:
1) Between 31 and 45 hours, not “more than 31”. Learn to read.
2) You’re confused between ‘men’ and ‘people’. Back then, most women that were in work worked part-time.
author: OliverCooper

text: The tweet you’re replying to literally rebuts your idiocy.
author: OliverCooper

text: Yep, Germany has the G7's only budget surplus.  Canada's budget this week showed a big uptick in borrowing (government had promised a surplus, but there'll be a $20bn deficit next year instead. Thanks Justin), so that's probably borderline. Don't know off the top of my head.
author: OliverCooper

text: Germany definitely, and I think Canada.
author: OliverCooper

text:
The government borrowed just £200m in February: a THIRD as much as expected and a SIXTH as much as in the same month last year.

Government debt as a share of GDP fell by 1.4% in the last year - with the UK now borrowing less than it has for 17 years.
author: OliverCooper

text: Of course you still remember your lines from your school play by heart - it was only last week.
author: OliverCooper

text: No, that definition is set by the International Labour Organisation, not “this government”. And as I literally just tweeted, fewer people in the UK work less than six hours a week than ever before. But you clearly don’t care about facts.
author: OliverCooper

text: That's not how percentages work.
author: OliverCooper

text: Very under-reported, but average wages have now been rising faster than average private-sector rents across the UK for three years straight.  Relative to wages, rent is now lower than it was in 2010.
author: OliverCooper

text: Although about two-thirds of companies that breach EU competition law get fined less than 1% of turnover, so it's by no means unduly lenient!
author: OliverCooper

text: Tab 7(1) here: https://www.ons.gov.uk/file?uri=/employmentandlabourmarket/peopleinwork/employmentandemployeetypes/datasets/summaryoflabourmarketstatistics/current/a01mar2019.xls …
author: OliverCooper

text:
Fact: In the last year, 1.4% of people in work averaged less than 6 hours a week. That's the lowest EVER.

Fact: In the last year, 54% of people in work averaged 31-45 hours a week. That's the highest EVER.

Do not believe Labour on the economy. It's almost always a lie.
author: OliverCooper

text: All part of @MahyarTousi's new video series: "Pints & Plagiarism"
author: OliverCooper

text: I’m really glad you told people this, because there is absolutely no other person in the world that would have used these exact - and I mean exact, precise, identical - words. And emojis.
author: OliverCooper

text: Absolutely. I posted this graph in January - proportion of the population over 16 in full-time work is now at an all-time record high (since then, of course, there have been a further 110,000 full-time jobs created!).
author: OliverCooper

text: Re-upping this thread of myths and reality about the UK labour market, which I posted last month but which applies even more so after today’s stellar jobs news.
author: OliverCooper

text: Parliament can change the law - as it made clear last Wednesday that it would.
author: OliverCooper

text: Really great news that the UK's breast cancer survival rate has risen by the most in Europe since 2009: with mortality rates falling 50% faster than in other big western European countries. Survival rates are now higher than in France, Germany, or Italy.
author: OliverCooper

text:
I’d better let ONS’s summary of today’s brilliant UK jobs market news say it all:
 Employment at an all-time high
 Unemployment below 4% for first time in 44 years
 Fewest people economically inactive ever
 Wages up 3.4% - almost twice the rate of inflation
author: OliverCooper

text: Dr Challoner’s Grammar School (@ChallonersGS)
author: OliverCooper

text: That part of Erskine May opens by saying “a motion or amendment” cannot be voted on again after being rejected. They apply equally. So Bercow has ruled that a second referendum cannot be legislated for this parliamentary session.
author: OliverCooper

text: Doesn't this mean that a Bill for a second referendum is now not able to be tabled again this session, as that was rejected on Thursday?
author: OliverCooper

text: YOU ARE WELCOME.
author: OliverCooper

text: Guido endorses MPs backing Britain's Withdrawal Agreement: "Brexit can be stopped, no deal Brexit is unlikely, so take the certain choice."
author: OliverCooper

text: Yes, the Magdala has been closed since 2016, but Camden Council rejected plans to re-open the ground floor as a pub and convert the first floor to residential earlier this month. http://camdennewjournal.com/article/pub-campaign-wins-as-plan-for-flat-above-famous-magdala-bar-is-thrown-out …
author: OliverCooper

text: Fiona Onasanya has a watertight and incontrovertible case that the 'courts' and 'media' refused to listen to.  She can't tell you what it is, but it's in her briefcase and it will prove her innocence.
author: OliverCooper

text: Erm... @GregHands and @DominicRaab?  I am informed that "Roger Moore attended for a year when he was evacuated during the war" doesn't count. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dr_Challoner%27s_Grammar_School …
author: OliverCooper

text: Precisely. Renewables will overtake gas as the UK's top source of electricity around 2022. That and the major shift of vehicles away from petrol/diesel to electricity, plus phasing out of gas for home heating (as announced last week), will cut emissions by a further 20-30%.
author: OliverCooper

text: Everyone’s commenting on Peterborough’s new skyline, but isn’t the bigger mistake the ‘window pane’ lines, which *make it look like she’s in a prison cell*?!
author: OliverCooper

text: If they're bought London property, it's not held offshore.
author: OliverCooper

text: CRS is pretty much bullet-proof for any financial accounts held outside the US.
author: OliverCooper

text: The UK’s amnesty for undeclared offshore earnings yielded just £70m. This was the last chance before HMRC automatically receives info on all bank accounts globally under CRS, so this implies there is FAR less wealth hidden offshore than is usually claimed.
author: OliverCooper

text: http://globalcarbonatlas.org/en/CO2-emissions …
author: OliverCooper

text: Good idea. And could children also be taught that since 2010, the UK has cut CO2 emissions by 50% more than any other major country? Because that seems not to be appreciated by a whole lot of people.
author: OliverCooper

text: Erm, Theresa May literally voted against ruling out No Deal just four days ago. She has not “joined them” - she just doesn’t have a majority.
author: OliverCooper

text: It's not a threat by Theresa May.  It's a threat by the half of MPs (mostly Labour and the SNP) that will block any outcomes except stopping Brexit altogether.  People like you have perhaps forgotten that the Government does not have a majority.
author: OliverCooper

text:
Support for Britain's Withdrawal Agreement among Conservative voters (YouGov):

Beginning of the week - 54% for, 26% against
End of the week - 68% for, 21% against

Conservatives are clearly and increasingly unanimously rallying around the deal, and Conservative MPs should, too.
author: OliverCooper

text: Ooh, I wonder where you got these great graphs from?! (cc @EssexCanning)
author: OliverCooper

text:
Name: Sebastian
Title: Li'l
author: OliverCooper

text: As well as St Patrick's Day, today is also the feast day of St Gertrude of Nivelles: patron saint of cats.  So happy Cat Day, everyone!
author: OliverCooper

text: I’ll bring Settlers, you bring Imperial Governor. Twilight Imperium is the apex game if there’s time!
author: OliverCooper

text: You, me, Greg, board game night?
author: OliverCooper

text: No, Jeremy - THIS sums up the Conservatives’ response to climate change.  #VoteBlueGoGreen
author: OliverCooper

text: Most of the country will be truly grateful that you’re backing Britain’s Deal, Antoinette. Even two months ago - before the EU’s further concessions - almost every voter segment backed the deal, with Leave voters saying it was acceptable by almost 2 to 1. https://www.ncpolitics.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/bloomberg-brexit-poll.pdf …
author: OliverCooper

text:
Why the hell is the Mirror running this front page?! The headline calls him an “angelic boy”. The 1st paragraph calls him a “hard-working fitness trainer”.

He’s a cold-blooded terrorist and that’s all he should be remembered as. Remember the victims; don’t humanise this monster.
author: OliverCooper

text: No, the CJEU would not decide such a question.  The CJEU would be asked the question of EU law, e.g. "Is X the EU legal order?"  The question of fact on what 'best endeavours' are would be answered by the Arbitration Panel.
author: OliverCooper

text: Lol
author: OliverCooper

text: Who encouraged them to be truant?  I'm glad pupils are demanding it, not that they're skipping school to do so - they can demand it much better by staying in school.  But I'm not sure you get anywhere by talking to them about truancy instead of climate change.
author: OliverCooper

text: The people that will be most affected by climate change are not those in government, but those in school - so it's right that pupils demand politicians take strong action on climate change.  I'm glad that this Conservative government is rising to the challenge. #VoteBlueGoGreen
author: OliverCooper

text:
This week, Chancellor @PhilipHammondUK unveiled a slew of new policies to tackle climate change:
 Future Homes Standard for renewable heating & efficiency
 Helping SMEs to decarbonise
 Ensuring everyone can carbon offset their flights
 Decarbonising the gas supply
author: OliverCooper

text: Thanks to the UK's massive adoption of renewables since 2010, electric vehicles are clean vehicles - and the number of new electric cars has surged 15-fold in the last five years, with the UK now home to the fifth-most electric cars in the world. #VoteBlueGoGreen
author: OliverCooper

text: The UK is helping shift the world away from fossil fuels, too. In 2017, the UK launched the Powering Past Coal Alliance to end coal use in developed countries by 2030. It now includes 30 countries, with Germany today saying it may join. #VoteBlueGoGreen
author: OliverCooper

text: Investors rate the UK as BY FAR the most attractive location to invest in renewable energy.  61% of institutional investors would consider investing in the UK renewables sector. #VoteBlueGoGreen
author: OliverCooper

text: The UK's biggest electricity producers have switched en masse to renewables, bringing tens of billions of investment into the sector.  Since 2010, renewable electricity generation by big producers has increased six-fold. #VoteBlueGoGreen
author: OliverCooper

text: Since 2010, the UK has increased renewable energy production four-fold.  Renewables have soared past nuclear and especially coal - the dirtiest form of energy, which has almost disappeared. #VoteBlueGoGreen
author: OliverCooper

text: Thanks to the UK cutting CO2 emissions by 25% since 2010, the UK's emissions are now at the level they were at in 1888 - and per person, they're lower than they've been since 1858: 160 years ago. #VoteBlueGoGreen
author: OliverCooper

text:
Good to see pupils once again demanding tough action against climate change.  Since 2010, the UK has been by far the most successful major economy at reducing CO2 emissions: 50% more than any other G20 country. #VoteBlueGoGreen

Thread
author: OliverCooper

text: No, what would happen is there'd be a reference to the CJEU (as with TFEU Art267) on a specific question of EU law, e.g. "Is X consistent with TFEU Article Y?" That judgment then goes back to the AP, which decides everything, including whether consistency with TFEU matters.
author: OliverCooper

text: Except it's just plain wrong.  The definition of 'best endeavours' is not a question of EU law.
author: OliverCooper

text: The CJEU doesn’t have a say in it.
author: OliverCooper

text: Sorry, that's clearly where we disagree.  In EU law, recitals unambiguously do not have independent weight (and thus an independent arbitrator would likely decide that EU institutions in negotiations conducted under the EU Treaties did not intend to give them independent weight).
author: OliverCooper

text: All those matters would be raised by the EU at arbitration - which is why UK should try to remove them - but a recital to a protocol just isn't going to be given much weight (especially as two paragraphs previously, it expressly says it doesn't relate to the future relationship).
author: OliverCooper

text: I strongly agree that PD should (and still could!) be amended to remove that, but it would be relatively little weight, given the Joint Interpretative Instrument trumps the Political Declaration (JII paras 7 and 10 expressly refer to ending customs alignment).
author: OliverCooper

text: If the EU only tables proposals it knows will be rejected (e.g. customs union), it is not employing best endeavours.  This fundamental breach means VCLT would not be required, as Joint Interpretative Instrument para14 expressly provides for unilateral suspension of the Protocol.
author: OliverCooper

text: To echo New Zealand PM Michael Savage in 1939, when confronted with the most hateful force in human history: both with gratitude for the past and confidence in the future, we range ourselves without fear besides New Zealand. Where she goes, we go. Where she stands, we stand.
author: OliverCooper

text:
New Zealand prides itself on being one of the most open, diverse, and generous countries on earth.

No matter what they claim, these terrorists stand against everything New Zealand represents. And their acts of evil cannot change that.
author: OliverCooper

text: I don't think fares complexity is what is stopping people from travelling by train.  Indeed, complexity is usually a consequence of demand management, i.e. train companies shifting passengers from busy trains to less busy trains.  Which boosts capacity and thus passenger numbers.
author: OliverCooper

text: A record 1,742 million journeys were made on the British rail network in 2018: up 1.5% compared to 2017 and up 137% since the introduction of competition in 1994-95.
author: OliverCooper

text: Surely e Day is 27 January? #eDay
author: OliverCooper

text: But if the Conservatives win the election, there's a mandate for the deal they would rather force an election than vote for, so the only purpose of wanting an election is for Labour to win?  Seems legit.
author: OliverCooper

text: But the UK's policy on international development is not for a level playing field, otherwise aid would be given to rich countries, too. I was just saying that those tariffs aren't about either revenue (as Erik asked) or protecting UK farmers (as you implied).
author: OliverCooper

text: The cloves and vanilla tariffs are purely about giving a subsidy to developing countries. The UK is maintaining the EU’s Anything But Arms policy, so all vanilla imports from least developed countries are tariff free, with the 6% tariff only applying to imports from non-LDCs.
author: OliverCooper

text:
One day I’ll turn on notifications for your tweets so I know when you’ve stolen my tweets.

Much like you’ve turned on notifications for my tweets so you know when to steal my tweets.
author: OliverCooper
